headline: The Whole Story with Anderson Cooper
subHeadline: Kamala Harris: Makling History. Aired 8-9p ET

utterances.speaker: PAMELA BROWN, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: So we look at all of that. This really is a true inside look at Joe Biden, the person and the politician. We speak to lawmakers. We speak to those in his inner circle and close friends to get that inner look.I hope you'll enjoy it.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: All right, Pamela, thank you. We'll be watching.Coming up next, two new hours of "THE WHOLE STORY WITH ANDERSON COOPER." "Kamala Harris, Making History," followed by "Joe Biden Passes the Torch." Thanks so much for joining me this evening. I'm Jessica Dean. We're going to see you again next weekend.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON COOPER, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Welcome to THE WHOLE STORY. I'm Anderson Cooper.In the last few days, Vice President Kamala Harris has kicked her presidential campaign into high gear, speaking to voters in Wisconsin, Indianapolis, and Texas. She's already picked up the endorsement of leading Democrats, including former president Barack Obama. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: KAMALA HARRIS, VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: In this moment, we are in a fight for our most fundamental freedoms. And to this room of leaders, I say bring it on. Bring it on. Bring it on.What kind of country do we want to live in? A country of freedom, compassion and rule of law? Or a country of chaos, fear, and hate? (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Soon after Kamala Harris became vice president, CNN's Abby Phillip sat down with her to talk about her immigrant routes, the difficulties and controversies she faced as a district attorney and attorney general in California, as well as her journey from prosecutor to politician.In light of her new campaign for the presidency, we wanted to take another look at what Harris had to say back then. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) ABBY PHILLIP, CNN ANCHOR (voice-over): Saturday, November 7th, 2020. At a driving celebration rally under the Delaware night sky, a historic victory for one woman and a win for women, girls, and people of color nationwide.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: Every little girl watching tonight sees that this is a country of possibilities.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Life's possibilities were something Kamala Harris was born to believe in.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: The soundtrack of my childhood was Aretha Franklin saying, you are young, gifted, and black.(MUSIC)

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: You know, it really was the soundtrack of my childhood. And being told by everyone and everything that you can do anything.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Harris' mother, Shyamala Gopalan, came to the University of California Berkeley with big dreams.

utterances.speaker: CAROL PORTER, CHILDHOOD FRIEND
utterances.sentences: Women from India and 19 didn't do that.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Childhood friend, Carol Porter.

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: Kamala seeing her mom, knowing her mom's journey, just that shows the possibilities of women.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Gopalan earned her master's degree and PhD. Eventually becoming a cancer researcher.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: My mother was quite a human being and an incredible mother.

utterances.speaker: MAYA HARRIS, SISTER
utterances.sentences: Our mother had great expectations for us. We could do and we could be anything.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Harris' his sister Maya.M. HARRIS: Our mother was very clear. It is not about you. It is about what you do.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: The Civil Rights Movement of the 1960s engulfed Berkeley in activism. It's where Gopalan fell in love with Donald Harris. Lenore Pomerance protested alongside them.LENORE POMERANCE, CLOSE FRIEND OF HARRIS' MOTHER: It was just part of our lives.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Just kind of an everyday thing.

utterances.speaker: POMERANCE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Being out on the streets. POMERANCEparticipated in, what you supported.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: I was very young. I was in a stroller. My mother would tell a story about, you know, at the time, strollers didn't have necessarily arm rests and seat belts. And so they're protesting and they're marching and they're into it, and they're, you know, marching for the people, and at one point, my uncle looks down and says, where's Kamala?(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: Our family consisted of a lot of aunts and uncles who were not born the brothers and sisters of my mother but in every way were my aunts and uncles. My Uncle Sherman at a very young age taught us how to play chess. He said, I want you to learn about that board. I want you to learn to think steps ahead. And the Sheltons and Miss Shelton, she was, you know, my second mother.

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: That's where Kamala grew up.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Regina Shelton ran a preschool downstairs from the Harris apartment.

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: When you walked in, there were pictures of prominent black people covering the wall. Maya Angelou, Rosa Parks, Martin Luther King, Malcolm X. So you are built up as a child of color or a black child to be proud of who you are, where you came from, and understand your history.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: It was more than just a school, more than just daycare.

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: It was --

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: It was a family.

utterances.speaker: POMERANCE
utterances.sentences: Mrs. Shelton's family would take the girls to a Christian church. Now, you was Shyamala Christian? She was a very spiritual person, but she wanted them to experience whenever there was there for them that would accept them and love them without abandoning anything of who she was. She was Indian.PHILLIP (voice-over): As a young child, Harris was bussed to school, an hour drive but a world away to an upper middle-class neighborhood. Do you think it changed the course of your life?

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: I don't know that it did. I certainly do think that there were so many resources being put into our education and at the earliest stages, which allowed me to be on a path to be able to blossom.PHILLIP (voice-over): A path that led her to Howard University.

utterances.speaker: JILL LOUIS, SORORITY SISTER
utterances.sentences: It was the opportunity to step out of minority and to step into the place of being part of the dominant culture.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Jill Lewis met Harris the night they were initiated into Alpha Kappa Alpha Incorporated, the oldest African-American sorority in the U.S. It was a time when anything seemed possible for this generation of young black students.

utterances.speaker: LOUIS
utterances.sentences: We were seeing things in the media like "The Cosby Show."

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Our new Miss America is Vanessa Williams.

utterances.speaker: LOUIS
utterances.sentences: Or like Vanessa Williams becoming Miss America. We could expect to be a part of corporations that we could have businesses, and you would find that people on campus dressed accordingly. In Kamala's case, be carrying a little briefcase around campus.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: She literally carried a briefcase around Howard campus?

utterances.speaker: LOUIS
utterances.sentences: Little briefcase. Little briefcase.PHILLIP (voice-over): By 1986, Harris graduated from Howard traveling back to San Francisco for law school. But her pathway to becoming a lawyer wasn't easy. She failed the bar exam on her first try. M. HARRIS: Mommy told us that life can be hard and you will have setbacks, and what's most important is to get up, dust yourself off, and keep going. And she took it again and she passed.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: And set her sights on being a prosecutor.M. HARRIS: She had a passion to stand up for people who are often not seen and not heard. She would be an advocate for people.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Early on, that advocacy was for young women. It was 2000, San Francisco was on fire.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Police say the violence begins when warring gangs --

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Assaults, drugs, violent gangs.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: The victims were sitting in this green car.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: And prostitution.Kamala Harris was a prosecutor at the city attorney's office leading the Family and Children Services Division.

utterances.speaker: LATEEFAH SIMON, PRESIDENT OF AKONADI FOUNDATION
utterances.sentences: I knew nothing about Kamala Harris until the day that she called me.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Lateefah Simon was a young single mom and a high school dropout on probation who managed to turn her life around and become the director of a local center for young women as a teenager.

utterances.speaker: SIMON
utterances.sentences: And she said, I'm a deputy city attorney and I hear that. You're working with girls, girls who are on the streets and girls who are being trafficked. She said let's work together. Let's change the system.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Harris launched a sex trafficking task force.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: A warrior who soon saw an opportunity. The current district attorney was having problems.

utterances.speaker: NICOLE ALLAN, ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: His conviction rate was extremely low. A lot of cases remained unsolved and morale was very low. Hallinan's office was frankly a mess.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Harris had worked under Hallinan years earlier. She knew she could clean up the mess. It was a gritty campaign. She needed someone to take charge.M. HARRIS: Our mother was feisty and a force of nature. Our mother put her whole heart into anything that we put our minds to.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: After a historic runoff with her mother standing by her side, Harris became the first black and South Asian American woman D.A. in San Francisco. Former adviser Debbie Mesloh remembers Harris was not going to cherish the victory sitting down because she couldn't.

utterances.speaker: DEBBIE MESLOH, FORMER ADVISER
utterances.sentences: No desk, no chair, no filing cabinet. Nothing. It was just very Kamala just to grab a chair from the reception and just start working.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: The work would get serious fast.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: I got the call that a police officer had been killed in line of duty.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: 29-year-old Isaac Espinoza was gunned down in the gang-ridden neighborhood of Bayview.

utterances.speaker: MESLOH
utterances.sentences: Isaac was an amazing cop. He's the type of person that you would hope would be out there protecting your community. PHILLIPdeath got worse when Harris made an unexpected announcement only three days after the shooting.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: In San Francisco, it is the will I believe of a majority of people that the most severe crimes be met with the most severe consequences, and that life without possibility of parole is a severe consequences.

utterances.speaker: GARY DELAGNES, SAN FRANCISCO POLICE OFFICERS ASSOCIATION
utterances.sentences: And I'm standing there and I'm going, oh, my god.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Former police union president Gary Delagnes was standing next to Harris when she made the announcement. He says the timing of that decision riled a police force already shaken with grief.

utterances.speaker: DELAGNES
utterances.sentences: You're thinking to yourself, OK, is she sorry that this kid died or is this just a political opportunity? What were her motives be to do this so soon after the death?

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: Now, from the first moments after the killing, I was actively involved in the case. And the bottom line is that as a prosecutor, you have to make decisions based on the facts and the law, period, no matter how everyone rightly feels about what happened.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: The controversy exploded at Espinoza's funeral.

utterances.speaker: ALLAN
utterances.sentences: It was a huge event in San Francisco. And Senator Dianne Feinstein got up and made a speech calling for the death penalty and she got a standing ovation.

utterances.speaker: MESLOH
utterances.sentences: All the police officers stood up and so Kamala was alone sitting down.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: In an op-ed published a week after the funeral, Harris said, in part, "The district attorney is charged with seeking justice, not vengeance. I am bound by oath and law to make decisions about what charges to bring, not based on emotion, anger, or politics within 48 hours of a suspect's arrest."

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: He should not have been killed. He should be alive today. And there was a lot of anger associated with that. And I understand that. But I made a decision as I was elected to do based on the facts and the law.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Harris' tenure as D.A. had its up and downs including a huge drug scandal inside the department.

utterances.speaker: ALLAN
utterances.sentences: It came out that technician for the San Francisco Police Department Crime Lab had been regularly skimming drugs from lab. And this mattered because she was frequently testifying in cases for people who had been caught with drugs.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Harris' office was aware of problems with the technician months earlier. Ultimately, hundreds of cases were dismissed.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: I was very upset about it. I was very upset about it. It resulted in an injustice for many people.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Despite the dismissals, Harris was determined to combat crime her way.

utterances.speaker: ALLAN
utterances.sentences: Back on Track is arguably one of her biggest successes as district attorney in San Francisco.

utterances.speaker: SIMON
utterances.sentences: Do these young people have bus passes? Do these young people have access to dental care? Do we have everything that we need to ensure they'll never come back into the system. The hardest job I've ever had.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Up next, Harris continues to climb the political ladder, while walking a tight rope.

utterances.speaker: LARA BAZELON, PROFESSOR, USF LAW
utterances.sentences: She had to be really careful. She had to walk a tight rope that white men who are more seen traditionally in these roles don't have to walk.(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: OPHA WINFREY, TV HOST
utterances.sentences: Superstar prosecutor Kamala Harris made history when she was elected California's first African-American female district attorney.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Kamala Harris' star was rising.President Obama took notice, too.

utterances.speaker: MESLOH
utterances.sentences: I think from the first days that they met they really saw a lot of themselves in each other.SEN. CATHERINE CORTEZ MASTO (D-NV): Kamala has a presence about her.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Senator Catherine Cortez Masto was the attorney general for neighboring Nevada.

utterances.speaker: CORTEZ MASTO
utterances.sentences: It's this confidence in not only who she is, but why she's there in the first place.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: She's California's most innovative district attorney.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Harris had just wrapped up seven years as San Francisco's D.A. Now she wanted to be California's top cop. HARRIS

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Her opponent, Los Angeles District Attorney Steve Cooley, came out swinging.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: Steve, I think that you really should not go below the dignity of this debate or the office we seek.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: A heated campaign that took weeks to declare a winner.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: I stand before you today, humbled to be chosen to be the next attorney general of the state of California.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Another historic victory for Harris becoming the first black and South Asian American woman elected as California's attorney general. But the victory was bittersweet.Your mother became ill.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: It was intense. It's -- the hospital visits, going to chemotherapy, and, you know, sitting there and hoping that you can make someone laugh while they're going through a horrible event. It is -- it is a very difficult time. Yes.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: How did you get through it?

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: One day at a time. One day at a time.

utterances.speaker: BRIAN NELSON, FORMER CALIFORNIA SPECIAL ASSISTANT ATTORNEY GENERAL
utterances.sentences: I was hired to do a couple of things but mortgage fraud wasn't one of them.PHILLIP (voice-over): Brian Nelson was Harris' special assistant attorney general.

utterances.speaker: NELSON
utterances.sentences: And I was deep in sort of the mortgage settlement negotiations with the largest five banks in the country.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: After the financial crash in 2008, states sued these banks for foreclosure abuses. California was among the hardest hit with banks filing foreclosures on over one million homes. That's when Harris pulled up her chair to the table.

utterances.speaker: NELSON
utterances.sentences: We're in that negotiations. She's talking to the banks. We're flying around the country, partnering with other AGs.

utterances.speaker: CORTEZ MASTO
utterances.sentences: There's leverage right in that force of all the states coming together to take on some of the banks and Wall Street. HARRIScrumbs on the table. So I pulled California out of the negotiations.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Standing in the trenches with Harris, Delaware's attorney general, Beau Biden.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: His state hadn't been as hard hit as many around the foreclosures, but Beau on a matter of principle said it's not right and I'm going to stand with you guys. It was incredible how much heat we took and Beau stood there. Beau stood there.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: The standoff paid off.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: As a result of 13 months of intense discussions, sometimes battle, we have delivered to California $18 billion in relief for California's homeowners.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Relief turned to reform when she revisited her Smart on Crime approach that she launched in San Francisco to crack down on truancy.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: Who are the homicide victims who are under the age of 25, who are they? A question that had not been asked. And it turned out 94 percent of them are high school dropouts.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Harris says she was trying to target social inequality, not families.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: If you have those kinds of absentee rates among a fluent neighborhood of elementary school students they'd be writing about it every day of the week. But what we were talking about are poor children, predominantly black children and Latino children. And I said we got to do something about this.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Was that the right role for the prosecutor's office to begin with?

utterances.speaker: BAZELON
utterances.sentences: The thought was, OK, we can use this big stick and scare the parents. And maybe if we do that and threaten criminal prosecution we can get the attendance numbers to go up.PHILLIP (voice-over): The program was successful in San Francisco, reducing truancy by almost a quarter over a two-year period. But as attorney general, the program backfired.

utterances.speaker: JON FAVREAU, POD SAVE AMERICA PODCAST HOST
utterances.sentences: Some parents were arrested because of that law. A couple went to jail.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: Unintended consequences, to be frank. When I was D.A., we never sent a parent to jail. My regret is that I have now heard stories that where in some jurisdiction DAs have criminalized the parents.

utterances.speaker: FAVREAU
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: And I regret that that has happened because that certainly was not the intention. Never was the intention. FAVREAU

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: For pundits, her intent has always been a balancing act.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Looking back on your record, do you think that you were walking that kind of tight rope as a woman, as a person of color walking into these rooms, as a prosecutor, trying to do things that people hadn't done before?

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: I did do things people hadn't done before. There's no question about that. And certainly there was plenty of pushback. It is just a fact that when you are trying to have people see things that they've never seen before, there's going to be reluctance if not objection to doing things differently. But you push forward and as people get to know you, they get to understand.PHILLIP (voice-over): Coming up, a star-studded romance begins on a blind date.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: It was literally a match made in Hollywood.

utterances.speaker: CHRISETTE HUDLIN, BEST FRIEND
utterances.sentences: Oh, my gosh. I must have known Kamala a good 20, 25 years before I met Doug.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Produced by an actual Hollywood heavyweight who just happens to be Harris' best friend. Chrisette Hudlin met entertainment lawyer Doug Emhoff when she needed legal advice in 2013.

utterances.speaker: HUDLIN
utterances.sentences: We were so impressed with him.

utterances.speaker: EMHOFF
utterances.sentences: And by the end of the hour, it was like, you know, you seem pretty cool, I might want to set you up with somebody the, you know, Kamala Harris. I'm like, Kamala Harris? The attorney general? And she said, yes, but I think it'd be great.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Hudlin immediately called her decades-old best friend.

utterances.speaker: HUDLIN
utterances.sentences: She was ignoring my calls. And I'm like, she has got to answer because this guy is going to be calling her.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: And you texted me that very same night. You were at the Lakers game.

utterances.speaker: EMHOFF
utterances.sentences: I was. And she said boo, Lakers.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: And I'm a Warriors fan. But I said go, Kobe or something.

utterances.speaker: EMHOFF
utterances.sentences: I was like, yes.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: And then --yes, you called me that morning. The next morning.

utterances.speaker: EMHOFF
utterances.sentences: So next I violated every rule of dating, I believe, with this long rambling voicemail, ended the call, and you remember that scene in "Swingers."

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And you should call me tomorrow. We're in two days, whatever. Anyway, my number --

utterances.speaker: EMHOFF
utterances.sentences: That was me, leaving a voicemail, and I thought I'd never hear from her. But then.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Harris had a break in her schedule and called him.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: We ended up talking for like 45 minutes to an hour and just laughing the whole time.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: A couple of days later, their first date.

utterances.speaker: EMHOFF
utterances.sentences: It felt like we had known each other and I just didn't want it to end. And so the next morning I pulled the move of e-mailing her with my availabilities for the next four months, including long weekends. And I said something like, I'm too old, had a ball, you're great. I want to see if we can make this work. Here's when I'm available next and I guess it worked.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: How did you feel about that?

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: I was terrified.(LAUGHTER) M. HARRIS: I knew Doug was the right one when I saw how he made her laugh because one of the things that Mommy used to always say is life will have its ups and downs. So you make sure that you find a life partner who makes you laugh. PHILLIP (voice-over): And in this case, a life partner with children.

utterances.speaker: EMHOFF
utterances.sentences: I had been a single dad for several years and I really wanted a partner, and then she came along and it just seemed like, what are we waiting for? Just meet the kids and let's just get on with our lives, and she put the brakes on it.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: My parents divorced when I was young. I know what it's like to be a kid of divorced parents and your parents start dating other people. And I did not want to bond with the kids if we weren't sure about what we had.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Eventually, they were sure. So Harris met Ella and Cole, Emhoff's children from his first marriage.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: It was actually more nerve wracking than our first date.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIPS
utterances.sentences: But they bonded immediately.

utterances.speaker: EMHOFF
utterances.sentences: One of the kids said, hey, there's an art exhibit at the school. Why don't we stop by? They never asked me to do that. Like this is pretty --this must be going great and so first time she meets the kids, first time we're at one of these art galleries, and then we're meeting a bunch of the parents at the school. She's meeting all their friends.

utterances.speaker: EMHOFF
utterances.sentences: I think they wanted a term that was just more personalized and expressed --

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: EMHOFF
utterances.sentences: There's a mom, Kerstin, and then there's a Momala, Kamala. And it just -- it evolved out of love and out of like we just want our own way to say mom.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: This modern family settled in for a couple of years before Harris' fast-moving career shifted into high gear.Did you know that you were getting on this kind of rocket ship when you decided to do this?

utterances.speaker: EMHOFF
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Has it sunk in?

utterances.speaker: EMHOFF
utterances.sentences: For our first couple of years it was none of this. It was just too busy professionals.PHILLIP (voice-over): But now everything has changed. When they sat down with us the army of Secret Service and support staff make their new reality impossible to ignore.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Thank you so much, sir, for your big idea.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: I think the entire world saw that literally in 2019 when you jumped up on the stage when someone was --

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: Indeed he did.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Someone -- I mean, you're laughing about it now, but it must have been a really scary moment. EMHOFFprotective of her because I love her and my family. And I think what you saw there was just a very, you know, no thought at all. There was no way I wasn't jumping up on that stage, which by the way was a real stage like this high. So as I'm running up there, I said, oh, my gosh, I've better get up there because -- but it's just pure instinct and, you know, I would do it again.

utterances.speaker: LOUIS
utterances.sentences: He got our undying support at that moment because that's what any one of us would have wanted to do for her is to protect her and to be there for her.

utterances.speaker: POMERANCE
utterances.sentences: So as a mother, this is kind of what you want for your child's partner. And it's heartbreaking that Shyamala hasn't been around to meet him. She would love him.PHILLIP (voice-over): And likely love all the places these two would go together.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: Let's march on.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: California attorney general Kamala Harris is expected to officially declare her run for the U.S. Senate.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Harris just filed her paperwork at the L.A. County Registrar's Office in Norwalk.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: It is the duty to be a bold leader.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: And Harris made a bold move.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: So I thank everyone here and at the top of my list, I thank my husband Doug Emhoff.(CHEERS AND APPLAUSE) SEN. CORY BOOKER (D-NJ): I was thrilled when she came to the Senate.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: New Jersey Senator Cory Booker.

utterances.speaker: BOOKER
utterances.sentences: You have to understand at that point I was the only African- American in my caucus. Just the fourth black person ever elected in the Senate. So I just knew the second black woman ever in the United States Senate with her gifts that the sky would be the limit.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: But for Harris.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: It's going to be a long night.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Election night 2016 wasn't entirely hopeful. WOLF BLITZER, CNN ANCHORpercent. He is ahead.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: What was going through your mind that night?

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: My nephew who at the time was 7, I think he was 7, came up to me with huge tears. He said Auntie Kamala, that man can't win. He was terrified. And I said, we will fight. We will fight, because there were a lot of folks who were terrified that night and continued to be terrified over four years.

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: Do you solemnly swear to support and defend the Constitution of the United States against all enemies, foreign and domestic?

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: When she was elected in the Senate, she was actually sworn in by Joe Biden.

utterances.speaker: LOUIS
utterances.sentences: You know, isn't life interesting and funny?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: You could see that they had this wonderful admiration for each other.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: In Washington, there's always sort of a trope that when you come into the Senate, you should kind of keep your head down.

utterances.speaker: BOOKER
utterances.sentences: Look, I was told to follow the Hillary Clinton model. I arrived, keep your head down, but she didn't have the luxury of that. She was needed.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: I believe we are a great country.PHILLIP (voice-over): Harris' first speech on the Senate floor a defense of immigrants.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: An undocumented immigrant is not a criminal.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Not just vocal, but surgical. A trained prosecutor in action. Grilling Trump administration officials and business leaders on Capitol Hill.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: Is that policy in writing somewhere?

utterances.speaker: JEFF SESSIONS, FORMER ATTORNEY GENERAL
utterances.sentences: I think so.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: So did you not consult it before you came before this committee knowing we would ask you questions about it?

utterances.speaker: SESSIONS
utterances.sentences: Well, we can.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: I do want you to be honest.

utterances.speaker: SESSIONS
utterances.sentences: But I'm not able to be rushed this fast. It makes me nervous.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: Can you give me a yes or no answer, please?ROD ROSENSTEIN, FORMER U.S. DEPUTY ATTORNEY: On a close briefing. Well, it's not a short answer. Senator, the answer is --

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: It is. Either you are willing to do that or not. Perhaps they suggested?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAM BARR, FORMER ATTORNEY GENERAL
utterances.sentences: I don't know. I wouldn't say suggest.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: Hinted?

utterances.speaker: BARR
utterances.sentences: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: Inferred? You don't know? OK. You've been asked several critical questions for which you don't have answers.

utterances.speaker: NELSON
utterances.sentences: That's the Kamala I know.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: NELSON
utterances.sentences: She follows the facts and she will get to the bottom of it.

utterances.speaker: CORTEZ MASTO
utterances.sentences: What you saw in those hearings is the Kamala that I saw in the rooms that we were with the banks and everyone else that we were challenged -- were challenging us on the foreclosure crisis. That's that who she is when she is set into to fight on behalf of this country and people that are in need.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: And I say this as a former prosecutor, we need a national use of force standard.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: After years of enforcing the law as a prosecutor, the Senate gave Harris a chance to change it, says Chris Cadelago, a reporter for "Politico."

utterances.speaker: CHRIS CADELAGO, NATIONAL POLITICAL REPORTER, POLITICO
utterances.sentences: No longer being so centrally a part of law enforcement, no longer being a leader in law enforcement freed her up to get behind these reforms.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: In some cases, shifting her position on issues like cash bail, which critics faulted her for enforcing as a prosecutor.SEN. RAND PAUL (R-KY): You know, the key thing is innocent until proven guilty. We're talking about an accusation.

utterances.speaker: CADELAGO
utterances.sentences: Really wasn't until she came to the Senate that she met with Rand Paul, a Republican from Kentucky, and they got together and came up with a plan. HARRISjustice policy.

utterances.speaker: CADELAGO
utterances.sentences: And a bill to allow states to look at this and come up with alternatives to cash bail.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: They found common ground on that issue, but Harris and Paul would clash over his objection to anti-lynching legislation.

utterances.speaker: PAUL
utterances.sentences: But this bill would cheapen the meaning of lynching by defining it so broadly as to include a minor bruise or abrasion.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Delivering one of her most emotional speeches on the Senate floor.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: Black lives have not been taken seriously as being fully human and deserving of dignity. And it should not require a maiming or torture.I approached Rand Paul early during the course of my time in the Senate about the need to reform America's money bail system. It is interesting to some, it was predictable to me, he said to me, Kamala, Appalachia loves this because there are poor people all over the country who know the injustice of this system. So we've found common ground. On the issue of my anti-lynching bill, we did not. And so we had a healthy debate on the floor of the Senate, and yes, I was outraged and disappointed with his position. And there you go.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: It was that outrage and those strong moments at hearings that gave Harris a more national presence. A presence that got people talking about the presidency.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: I stand before you today.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Harris' run for the White House when we return.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: It was the end of June, 2019, the highly anticipated first Democratic presidential debate.M. HARRIS: It was such a huge field, a diverse field.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Was there a sense that she needed a big moment?M. HARRIS: I think everyone goes into the presidential debate certainly wanting to be remembered.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: This economy is not working for working people.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: The opportunity came and in a sea of candidates, the eyes of the nation were focused on just two.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: You also worked with him to oppose bussing, and you know, there was a little girl in California who was part of the second class to integrate her public schools. And she was bused to school every day, and that little girl was me.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: It was a breakthrough Harris needed.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: After the debate I really confirmed my support for her.M. HARRIS: People learned something about her and her background that they didn't know in that moment.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: A pivotal moment for a campaign that began less than a year earlier with high hopes.

utterances.speaker: BOOKER
utterances.sentences: I knew she was a person of destiny.

utterances.speaker: SIMON
utterances.sentences: There were tens of thousands, maybe millions of women of color and our allies who surrounded Kamala and love when she ran because folks saw themselves.CECILY STRONG, COMEDIAN, "SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE": California Senator Kamala Harris.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: That viral moment may have been a sugar high.MAYA RUDOLPH, COMEDIAN, "SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE": That little girl you just introduced, that little girl was me.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: By the fall, her numbers came back to earth. So Harris doubled down on the first caucus state of Iowa.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: Thank you for being here.

utterances.speaker: CADELAGO
utterances.sentences: Her campaign felt like the more people saw Kamala particularly in these unguarded moments in people's homes and their living rooms, that they would come to really know her and really like her.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: Are we going to have Sunday family dinner? Yes?

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: But ultimately, it wasn't enough.

utterances.speaker: CADELAGO
utterances.sentences: People were interested. They were excited. But it was just too late. There weren't enough of them. They had already fallen for other candidates.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: At the caucuses.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: And she ran out of money by December 3rd before any caucus, any vote had even happened.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: I am suspending our campaign today.Making a decision to get out of a race is probably as difficult as making a decision to get into a race.

utterances.speaker: BOOKER
utterances.sentences: Kamala Harris is a glass ceiling breaker, name taker, history maker. If somebody like her could not make it that far what does it say about our country with somebody of that qualifications?

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: But some of her qualifications, like her career as a prosecutor, became a source of criticism from both sides of the aisle.Do you feel like you were misunderstood?

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: There are a lot of nuances and what it means to be a prosecutor, especially in this moment that is I think long overdue, where America is coming to a reckoning on a lot of issues that deal with racial injustice.PHILLIP (voice-over): People inside and outside the campaign say her candidacy was hurt by disorganization, infighting and mixed messaging.

utterances.speaker: CADELAGO
utterances.sentences: There were constant disagreements over strategy and message and direction.M. HARRIS: And when you look at how everything unfolded, so many people entered the race for the presidency, most people didn't go the distance.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: But it turns out Harris would end up going the distance. But in a different direction.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Would you consider because Senator Harris as a running mate?

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Of course I would.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Harris' old friendship with Biden's son, Beau, who died in 2015, made her path a little easier.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: Beau was an extraordinary human being and we became very close. I got to know Joe, his father, as a person.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Perhaps not so surprising then when the call came on August 11th, 2020.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: OK, sorry to keep you.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: That's all right. You ready to go to work?

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: The answer is absolutely yes, Joe, and I am ready to work. I am ready to do this with you, for you, I'm just deeply honored and I'm very excited.M. HARRIS: Some people would say, well, you know, that's one of the world's greatest comeback stories. Maybe second only to Joe Biden together.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Together they'd fight Donald Trump. And eventually history would be made.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: While I may be the first woman in this office, I will not be the last.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Surrounded by those who love and inspire her. Yet missing the one who started it all.M. HARRIS: Our mother would be so proud. She would be so proud.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Do you think that she always saw this for you, in you? Did she raise you to do this?

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: She did not raise me to be vice president of the United States, but she did raise me and my sister to believe that we could do anything if we put the hard work into it and there you are. There you are.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: And here she is, a woman of color, a wife, a prosecutor, a senator the vice president of the United States of America, and now the presumptive Democratic nominee for president. The first in so many ways and so many times.Kamala Harris has once again made history.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: Good evening.(END VIDEOTAPE)
